books.title: The Memories of Sherlock Holmes
books.description: The fantastic and visionary world of Tim Burton, in a rich volume that celebrates his dreamlike and grotesque style, developed over 30 years of great successes Published to accompany an exhibition at the Museo Nazionale del Cinema, Turin, 10 October 2023 - 7 April 2024 Text in English and Italian

books.title: Mrs Dalloway
books.description: Society hostess, Clarissa Dalloway is giving a party. Her thoughts and sensations on that one day, and the interior monologues of others whose lives are interwoven with hers gradually reveal the characters of the central protagonists. Clarissa's life is touched by tragedy as the events in her day run parallel to those of Septimus Warren Smith, whose madness escalates as his life draws toward inevitable suicide.

books.title: Crime and Punishment
books.description: Raskolnikov, a destitute and desperate former student, commits a random murder without remorse or regret, imagining himself to be a great man far above moral law. But as he embarks on a dangerous cat-and-mouse game with a suspicious police investigator, his own conscience begins to torment him and he seeks sympathy and redemption from Sonya, a downtrodden prostitute.

books.title: The Book of Disquiet
books.description: Seated at his desk in the Lisbon's Rua dos Douradores, Bernardo Soares, an assistant book-keeper, writes his diary-a self-deprecating reflection on the sheer distance between the loftiness of his feelings and the humdrum reality of his everyday life.

books.title: Invisible Cities
books.description: Imaginary conversations between Marco Polo and his host, the Chinese ruler Kublai Khan, conjure up cities of magical times. “Of all tasks, describing the contents of a book is the most difficult and in the case of a marvelous invention like Invisible Cities, perfectly irrelevant” (Gore Vidal).

books.title: Paradise Lost
books.description: In Paradise Lost Milton produced poem of epic scale, conjuring up a vast, awe-inspiring cosmos and ranging across huge tracts of space and time, populated by a memorable gallery of grotesques. And yet, in putting a charismatic Satan and naked, innocent Adam and Eve at the centre of this story, he also created an intensely human tragedy on the Fall of Man. Written when Milton was in his fifties - blind, bitterly disappointed by the Restoration and in danger of execution - Paradise Lost's apparent ambivalence towards authority has led to intense debate about whether it manages to 'justify the ways of God to men', or exposes the cruelty of Christianity.

books.title: Norwegian Wood
books.description: Toru, a quiet and preternaturally serious young college student in Tokyo, is devoted to Naoko, a beautiful and introspective young woman, but their mutual passion is marked by the tragic death of their best friend years before.  Toru begins to adapt to campus life and the loneliness and isolation he faces there, but Naoko finds the pressures and responsibilities of life unbearable.  As she retreats further into her own world, Toru finds himself reaching out to others and drawn to a fiercely independent and sexually liberated young woman.

books.title: The Path to the Spiders' Nests
books.description: Italo Calvino was only twenty-three when he first published this bold and imaginative novel. It tells the story of Pin, a cobbler's apprentice in a town on the Ligurian coast during World War II. He lives with his sister, a prostitute, and spends as much time as he can at a seedy bar where he amuses the adult patrons. After a mishap with a Nazi soldier, Pin becomes involved with a band of partisans. Calvino's portrayal of these characters, seen through the eyes of a child, is not only a revealing commentary on the Italian resistance but an insightful coming-of-age story.

books.title: Kitchen
books.description: Kitchen is an enchantingly original book that juxtaposes two tales about mothers, love, tragedy, and the power of the kitchen and home in the lives of a pair of free-spirited young women in contemporary Japan. Mikage, the heroine, is an orphan raised by her grandmother, who has passed away. Grieving, Mikage is taken in by her friend Yoichi and his mother (who is really his cross-dressing father) Eriko. As the three of them form an improvised family that soon weathers its own tragic losses, Yoshimoto spins a lovely, evocative tale with the kitchen and the comforts of home at its heart.

books.title: The Lover
books.description: Set in the prewar Indochina of Marguerite Duras's childhood, this is the haunting tale of a tumultuous affair between an adolescent French girl and her Chinese lover. In spare yet luminous prose, Duras evokes life on the margins of Saigon in the waning days of France's colonial empire, and its representation in the passionate relationship between two unforgettable outcasts.

books.title: The Great Gatsby
books.description: Set in the summer of 1922, The Great Gatsby explores the lives of the wealthy elite in the fictional East and West Egg. F. Scott Fitzgerald's classic tale of love, wealth, and the American Dream is both a critique of the Roaring Twenties and a timeless exploration of human nature.

books.title: To Kill a Mockingbird
books.description: Harper Lee's poignant exploration of racial injustice in the American South follows the story of Scout Finch, her brother Jem, and their father, the principled lawyer Atticus Finch. The novel is a powerful portrayal of morality, compassion, and the struggle for justice.

George Orwell's dystopian masterpiece, 1984, presents a chilling vision of a totalitarian society where the government, led by the omnipresent Big Brother, controls every aspect of citizens' lives. A cautionary tale about the dangers of unchecked power and the erosion of individual freedoms.

books.title: Pride and Prejudice
books.description: Jane Austen's classic novel of manners and love follows the spirited Elizabeth Bennet as she navigates the social norms and expectations of early 19th-century England. Pride and Prejudice is a timeless exploration of societal expectations, personal growth, and the complexities of romance.

books.title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
books.description: Gabriel García Márquez's magical realist novel chronicles the Buendía family across generations in the fictional town of Macondo. Richly woven with elements of fantasy and folklore, One Hundred Years of Solitude is a literary masterpiece that explores the cyclical nature of history and the human condition.

books.title: Moby-Dick
books.description: Herman Melville's epic tale of Captain Ahab's obsessive quest for revenge against the elusive white whale, Moby-Dick, is a symbolic exploration of humanity's relationship with nature and the consequences of unchecked ambition.

books.title: The Catcher in the Rye
books.description: J.D. Salinger's coming-of-age novel follows the rebellious teenager Holden Caulfield as he navigates the challenges of adolescence and grapples with the phoniness of the adult world. A timeless exploration of alienation, identity, and the search for authenticity.

books.title: The Lord of the Rings
books.description: J.R.R. Tolkien's epic fantasy trilogy follows the quest to destroy the One Ring and defeat the dark lord Sauron. The Lord of the Rings is a classic tale of heroism, friendship, and the struggle between good and evil.

books.title: The Grapes of Wrath
books.description: John Steinbeck's powerful novel portrays the struggles of the Joad family as they journey west during the Great Depression. The Grapes of Wrath is a poignant exploration of poverty, social injustice, and the indomitable human spirit.

books.title: The Hobbit
books.description: J.R.R. Tolkien's classic adventure follows Bilbo Baggins as he joins a group of dwarves on a quest to reclaim their homeland from the fearsome dragon Smaug. The Hobbit is a charming tale of bravery, friendship, and unexpected heroism.

books.title: Wuthering Heights
books.description: Emily Brontë's dark and passionate tale of love and revenge unfolds on the moors of Yorkshire. Wuthering Heights explores the destructive power of obsession and the enduring nature of true love.

books.title: Brave New World
books.description: Aldous Huxley's dystopian novel envisions a future society where individuals are conditioned for conformity, pleasure, and societal stability. Brave New World is a thought-provoking exploration of the consequences of sacrificing individuality for societal harmony.

books.title: Frankenstein
books.description: Mary Shelley's groundbreaking work of science fiction explores the consequences of scientific hubris as Dr. Victor Frankenstein creates a creature that becomes a tragic symbol of isolation and rejection.

books.title: The Odyssey
books.description: Homer's ancient epic follows the hero Odysseus on his perilous journey home after the Trojan War. The Odyssey is a timeless tale of adventure, perseverance, and the enduring power of cunning and wit.

books.title: Jane Eyre
books.description: Charlotte Brontë's classic novel tells the story of the orphaned and mistreated Jane Eyre as she overcomes adversity, finds love, and discovers her own strength. A timeless exploration of social class, morality, and the pursuit of personal happiness.

books.title: The Brothers Karamazov
books.description: Fyodor Dostoevsky's final novel explores the complex relationships and philosophical dilemmas within the Karamazov family. A profound examination of faith, morality, and the search for meaning.

books.title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
books.description: Oscar Wilde's provocative novel follows the life of Dorian Gray, a man whose portrait ages while he remains young and beautiful. The Picture of Dorian Gray is a philosophical exploration of morality, decadence, and the consequences of indulgence.

books.title: Anna Karenina
books.description: Leo Tolstoy's epic novel explores the tragic consequences of an illicit love affair between Anna Karenina and Count Vronsky. A sweeping portrayal of Russian society and a profound meditation on love, morality, and societal expectations.

books.title: The Iliad
books.description: Homer's ancient epic poem recounts the events of the Trojan War and the heroics of Achilles. The Iliad is a timeless exploration of honor, glory, and the consequences of war.

books.title: The Silmarillion
books.description: J.R.R. Tolkien's posthumously published work delves into the mythology and history of Middle-earth. The Silmarillion is a rich tapestry of tales, exploring the creation of the world, the struggles of elves and men, and the ultimate battle between good and evil.

books.title: Siddhartha
books.description: Hermann Hesse's philosophical novel follows the spiritual journey of Siddhartha as he seeks enlightenment and self-discovery. Siddhartha is a timeless exploration of the quest for meaning and the pursuit of inner peace.

books.title: Les Misérables
books.description: Victor Hugo's epic novel tells the story of Jean Valjean, a former convict seeking redemption, and the lives of those he encounters in post-revolutionary France. Les Misérables is a sweeping tale of justice, love, and the human spirit.

books.title: The Hunchback of Notre-Dame
books.description: Victor Hugo's Gothic novel explores the tragic fate of Quasimodo, the hunchbacked bell ringer of Notre-Dame Cathedral, and his unrequited love for the beautiful Esmeralda. A tale of love, prejudice, and the enduring power of kindness.

books.title: A Tale of Two Cities
books.description: Charles Dickens' historical novel unfolds against the backdrop of the French Revolution and follows the lives of several characters in London and Paris. A Tale of Two Cities is a timeless exploration of sacrifice, resurrection, and the tumultuous forces of social change.

books.title: The Count of Monte Cristo
books.description: Alexandre Dumas' adventure novel tells the story of Edmond Dantès, who, betrayed and wronged, seeks revenge as the mysterious and wealthy Count of Monte Cristo. A tale of justice, betrayal, and the enduring power of hope.

books.title: The Canterbury Tales
books.description: Geoffrey Chaucer's collection of stories follows a diverse group of pilgrims on their journey to Canterbury. The Canterbury Tales is a masterful exploration of human nature, morality, and the social fabric of medieval England.

books.title: The War of the Worlds
books.description: H.G. Wells' classic science fiction novel recounts the invasion of Earth by Martians. The War of the Worlds is a groundbreaking work that explores themes of colonialism, survival, and the fragility of human civilization.

books.title: The Scarlet Letter
books.description: Nathaniel Hawthorne's novel explores the consequences of adultery as Hester Prynne grapples with her sin and society's judgment. The Scarlet Letter is a timeless exploration of guilt, redemption, and the complexities of human nature.

books.title: The Divine Comedy
books.description: Dante Alighieri's epic poem follows the journey of the soul through Hell, Purgatory, and Heaven. The Divine Comedy is a profound exploration of theology, morality, and the human condition.

books.title: The Jungle Book
books.description: Rudyard Kipling's collection of stories follows the adventures of Mowgli, a young boy raised by wolves in the jungles of India. The Jungle Book is a timeless exploration of the balance between humans and nature.

books.title: The Three Musketeers
books.description: Alexandre Dumas' swashbuckling adventure follows the escapades of d'Artagnan and the three musketeers as they navigate the political intrigues of 17th-century France. A tale of friendship, loyalty, and daring exploits.

books.title: Gulliver's Travels
books.description: Jonathan Swift's satirical novel recounts the adventures of Lemuel Gulliver as he travels to fantastical lands inhabited by curious creatures. Gulliver's Travels is a witty exploration of human nature, society, and political satire.

books.title: The Wind in the Willows
books.description: Kenneth Grahame's charming tale follows the adventures of anthropomorphic animals, including Mole, Ratty, Toad, and Badger. The Wind in the Willows is a timeless exploration of friendship, camaraderie, and the joys of the English countryside.

books.title: The Idiot
books.description: Prince Myshkin, a naive and kind-hearted man, returns to Russia and finds himself entangled in the complex web of societal intrigues. As he navigates through the treacherous world of aristocrats and schemers, his innocence becomes both a source of fascination and vulnerability.

books.title: The Gambler
books.description: Set against the backdrop of a European casino, The Gambler explores the destructive allure of addiction and the complexities of human desire. Alexei Ivanovich, a young tutor, finds himself entangled in the world of high-stakes gambling, leading to a tumultuous journey of risk, love, and self-discovery.

books.title: Kafka on the Shore
books.description: In this surreal and thought-provoking novel, Haruki Murakami weaves together the lives of a teenage runaway named Kafka and an elderly man named Nakata. As their paths intertwine, the narrative explores themes of identity, destiny, and the mystical connections that bind us.

books.title: 1Q84
books.description: Set in an alternate reality where two moons hang in the sky, 1Q84 explores the lives of Aomame and Tengo, whose destinies become entwined in a strange and mesmerizing world. As they navigate through the layers of reality, the novel delves into themes of love, power, and the nature of existence.

books.title: Moderato Cantabile
books.description: Set in a small French town, Moderato Cantabile tells the story of a woman named Anne Desbaresdes and her encounters with a mysterious man. Through their conversations, the novel explores themes of desire, societal norms, and the complexities of human relationships.

books.title: Critique of Pure Reason
books.description: A foundational work in Western philosophy, Kant's Critique of Pure Reason explores the nature of human knowledge and the limits of reason. Delving into epistemology and metaphysics, Kant challenges traditional views on perception and sets the stage for his groundbreaking philosophical system.

books.title: Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals
books.description: In this influential work, Kant lays the groundwork for his moral philosophy. Examining the concept of duty and the categorical imperative, he explores the principles that should guide ethical decision-making. A timeless exploration of morality and human responsibility.

books.title: The Importance of Being Earnest
books.description: A comedic masterpiece, The Importance of Being Earnest satirizes Victorian society and its absurdities. Wilde's witty dialogue and clever plot twists follow the humorous antics of characters living double lives, highlighting the farcical nature of social expectations.

books.title: Tender Is the Night
books.description: Set against the backdrop of the French Riviera, Tender Is the Night explores the complex lives of Dick and Nicole Diver. As their glamorous world unravels, Fitzgerald weaves a narrative of love, ambition, and the disintegration of dreams in the face of personal and societal challenges.

books.title: Eugene Onegin
books.description: A novel in verse, Eugene Onegin tells the story of the titular character and his interactions with the young Tatyana. Pushkin's poetic masterpiece explores themes of love, societal norms, and the consequences of pride and rejection.

books.title: War and Peace
books.description: A monumental work in world literature, War and Peace spans the lives of various aristocratic families in Russia during the Napoleonic Wars. Tolstoy's epic novel explores the intricacies of human nature, the futility of war, and the search for meaning in the face of existential questions.

books.title: The Hound of the Baskervilles
books.description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John Watson are summoned to the gloomy Baskerville Hall to investigate the mysterious death of Sir Charles Baskerville. As they uncover clues and face supernatural legends, the duo must navigate a web of deception to uncover the truth behind the ancient curse that haunts the Baskerville family.

books.title: Maigret and the Yellow Dog
books.description: Chief Inspector Maigret is called to the tranquil town of Concarneau to investigate the murder of a nightclub owner. As he delves into the lives of the town's residents, Maigret navigates a maze of secrets and motives. Simenon's masterful storytelling brings the enigmatic detective face to face with the complexities of human nature.

books.title: The Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin
books.description: Written by Benjamin Franklin, one of the Founding Fathers of the United States, this autobiography offers a firsthand account of Franklin's life. From his early days in Boston to his experiments with electricity and contributions to the drafting of the U.S. Constitution, Franklin's narrative provides insights into his intellect, wit, and the shaping of American history.

books.title: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
books.description: In a post-apocalyptic future, bounty hunter Rick Deckard is tasked with 'retiring' rogue androids. As he questions the nature of humanity and reality, Dick's masterpiece explores themes of empathy, artificial intelligence, and the blurred lines between man and machine.

books.title: Ubik
books.description: In a world where psychic powers and reality-bending technologies exist, Ubik follows Joe Chip as he navigates a series of mind-bending events. Dick's surreal narrative challenges the perception of reality, time, and the nature of existence itself.

books.title: The 10th Victim
books.description: Set in a future society where legalized murder is a form of entertainment, The 10th Victim explores the twisted game of cat and mouse between hunters and victims. Robert Sheckley's satirical and darkly humorous novel delves into the consequences of a society obsessed with violence and celebrity.

books.title: Solaris
books.description: Solaris, set on a distant space station, follows psychologist Kris Kelvin as he encounters mysterious phenomena on the planet Solaris. Lem's novel explores the limits of human understanding, consciousness, and the enigmatic nature of extraterrestrial intelligence.

books.title: Phenomenology of Spirit
books.description: Hegel's Phenomenology of Spirit is a cornerstone of philosophical thought. Exploring the evolution of consciousness, self-awareness, and the dialectical process, this profound work delves into the complexities of human experience and the development of absolute knowledge.

books.title: Science of Logic
books.description: In Science of Logic, Hegel presents a comprehensive exploration of logic and metaphysics. Examining the nature of thought and reality, this influential work lays the groundwork for Hegel's philosophical system, addressing concepts of being, essence, and the development of categories.

books.title: The Complete Poems of Emily Dickinson
books.description: This collection gathers the complete poems of Emily Dickinson, showcasing her unique voice and unconventional style. Dickinson's poems explore themes of nature, love, death, and the mysteries of existence, leaving a lasting impact on American literature.

books.title: To the Lighthouse
books.description: To the Lighthouse is Virginia Woolf's landmark novel that explores the dynamics of a family's relationships and the passage of time. Set against the backdrop of the Isle of Skye, the novel delves into the complexities of human consciousness and the shifting nature of perception.

books.title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
books.description: Lewis Carroll's timeless classic, Alice's Adventures in Wonderland, takes readers on a whimsical journey through a fantastical world. Filled with eccentric characters and surreal landscapes, the story follows Alice as she encounters peculiar creatures and navigates the absurdities of Wonderland.
